{{short description|Inappropriately releasing homeless or indigent patients}} {{worldwide|date=January 2020}}{{Discrimination sidebar|state=collapsed}} [[File:US Army 51483 260th Soldiers Stand Down for Homelessness.jpg|thumb|Homeless veteran receives medical treatment. Homeless patients are one of the groups who are especially vulnerable to patient dumping.<ref name="Hochron_2013" />]] '''Patient dumping''' or '''homeless dumping''' is the practice of [[hospital]]s and [[emergency service]]s inappropriately releasing [[homeless]] or indigent patients to public hospitals or on the streets instead of placing them with a [[homeless shelter]] or retaining them, especially when they may require expensive medical care with minimal government reimbursement from [[Medicaid]] or [[Medicare (United States)|Medicare]].<ref>{{cite news |title=Dumped On Skid Row |url=http://www.cbsnews.com/stories/2007/05/17/60minutes/main2823079.shtml |publisher=[[60 Minutes]] |date= May 17, 2007|access-date=2007-05-21 }}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=L.A. charges hospital in dumping of homeless |url=http://www.nbcnews.com/id/15752013 |publisher=[[NBC News]] |date=November 16, 2006 |access-date=2007-05-21 }}</ref><ref name="Abel_2011" /><ref name="Rice_1992">{{cite journal | vauthors = Rice MF, Jones W | title = The uninsured and patient dumping: recent policy responses in indigent care | journal = Journal of the National Medical Association | volume = 83 | issue = 10 | pages = 874–80 | date = October 1991 | pmid = 1800761 | pmc = 2571592 }}</ref> The term homeless dumping has been used since the late 19th century and resurfaced throughout the 20th century alongside legislation and policy changes aimed at addressing the issue.<ref name="Abel_2011" /> Studies of the issue have indicated mixed results from the United States' policy interventions and have proposed varying ideas to remedy the problem.<ref name="Rice_1992" /><ref name=":3">{{Cite journal|last=O'Brien|first=Hylton, Maria|date=1992|title=The Economics and Politics of Emergency Health Care for the Poor: The Patient Dumping Dilemma|url=https://digitalcommons.law.byu.edu/lawreview/vol1992/iss4/14|journal=BYU Law Review|language=en|volume=1992|issue=4}}</ref><ref name=":2" />
== History ==
=== Early history === The term "patient dumping" was first mentioned in several [[The New York Times|''New York Times'']] articles published in the late 1870s, which described the practice of private New York hospitals transporting poor and sickly patients by horse drawn ambulance to [[NYC Health + Hospitals/Bellevue|Bellevue Hospital]], the city's preeminent public facility.<ref name="Abel_2011">{{cite journal | vauthors = Abel E | title = Patient dumping in New York City, 1877-1917 | journal = American Journal of Public Health | volume = 101 | issue = 5 | pages = 789–95 | date = May 2011 | pmid = 21421951| doi = 10.2105/AJPH.2010.300005 | pmc = 3076414 }}</ref> The jarring ride and lack of stabilized care typically resulted in death of the patient and outrage of the public.<ref name="Abel_2011" /> Scholars report that private hospital administrations were motivated by a desire to keep mortality rates and costs down when they advised ambulance drivers to send poor patients in critical condition directly to the public hospitals like Bellevue even if a private hospital was closer.<ref name="Abel_2011" /> After the deaths associated with patient dumping or inappropriate patient transfer added up, the first attempt at legislative reform in the United States was pushed through the New York Senate around 1907, largely by [[Julius Harburger]].<ref name="Abel_2011" /> The legislation penalized private hospitals when they sent ill patients away or obligated staff to transfer them to another hospital.<ref name="Abel_2011" /> Notwithstanding the passage of city ordinances prohibiting the practice, it continued.<ref name="Abel_2011" /> The practice of patient dumping continued for several decades, and in the 1960s it was brought back into the public eye by the media, but not much was done to resolve the issue.<ref name="Abel_2011" /> Many [[Homelessness and mental health|homeless people who have mental health problems]] can no longer find a place in a [[psychiatric hospital]] because of the trend towards mental health [[deinstitutionalization]] from the 1960s onwards.<ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Scherl DJ, Macht LB | title = Deinstitutionalization in the absence of consensus | journal = Hospital & Community Psychiatry | volume = 30 | issue = 9 | pages = 599–604 | date = September 1979 | pmid = 223959 | doi = 10.1176/ps.30.9.599 }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Rochefort DA | title = Origins of the "Third psychiatric revolution": the Community Mental Health Centers Act of 1963 | journal = Journal of Health Politics, Policy and Law | volume = 9 | issue = 1 | pages = 1–30 | date = Spring 1984 | pmid = 6736594 | doi = 10.1215/03616878-9-1-1 }}</ref> It continues to this day especially in New York City, where Bellevue receives a large share of Manhattan’s indigent.
=== 1980s resurface in the public eye and policy interventions === "Patient dumping" resurfaced in the 1980s, nationwide, with private hospitals refusing to examine or treat the poor and uninsured in the emergency departments (ED) and transferring them to public hospitals for further care and treatment.<ref name="Abel_2011" /><ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Schiff RL, Ansell DA, Schlosser JE, Idris AH, Morrison A, Whitman S | title = Transfers to a public hospital. A prospective study of 467 patients | journal = The New England Journal of Medicine | volume = 314 | issue = 9 | pages = 552–7 | date = February 1986 | pmid = 3945293 | doi = 10.1056/NEJM198602273140905 }}</ref><ref>{{cite book|last1=Stevens|first1=Rosemary A.|last2=Rosenberg|first2=Charles E.|last3=Burns|first3=Lawton R. | name-list-style = vanc |title=History and health policy in the United States putting the past back in|date=2006|publisher=Rutgers University Press|location=New Brunswick, N.J.|isbn=978-0-8135-3838-9|pages=280}}</ref> In 1987 33 complaints of patient dumping were made to the US Department of Health and Human Services, and the following year 1988, 185 complaints were made.<ref name="Rice_1992" /> Since private hospitals ceased publishing their mortality rates, analysts pointed to high costs of dealing with Medicaid's reimbursements and uninsured patients as the motivation.<ref name="Abel_2011" /> This refusal of care resulted in patient deaths and public outcry culminating with the passage of a federal anti-patient dumping law in 1986 known as the [[Emergency Medical Treatment and Active Labor Act]] (EMTALA).<ref name="Abel_2011" /> In 1985 the [[Consolidated Omnibus Budget Reconciliation Act of 1985|Consolidated Omnibus Budget Reconciliation Act]] (COBRA) was passed which was meant to regulate how patients were transferred and also end patient dumping.<ref name="Brider_1987">{{cite journal | vauthors = Brider P | title = Too poor to pay: the scandal of patient dumping | journal = The American Journal of Nursing | volume = 87 | issue = 11 | pages = 1447–9 | date = November 1987 | pmid = 3674130 | doi = 10.2307/3425901 | jstor = 3425901 }}</ref> COBRA was not a complete solution, and in the years after its passage hospitals struggled with creating appropriate discharge protocols and the cost of providing health care for homeless patients.<ref name="Brider_1987" /> Statistically, Texas and Illinois had the highest rates of patient dumping because of economic difficulties.<ref name="Rice_1992" /> Researchers have reported that the language in COBRA was not precise enough to significantly disincentivise healthcare providers to discontinue patient dumping practices.<ref name=":3" /> For example, in the 1980s Texas state law had a loop hole that allowed hospitals to transfer patients to nursing homes.<ref name="Rice_1992" />
=== Early 21st century policy === Homeless dumping continued to be an issue in the United States into the 21st century.<ref name="Abel_2011" /> University of California Los Angeles professor Abel (2011) claimed that these policy interventions have not been effective because the United States' health care system is too heavily influenced by the patients ability to pay.<ref name="Abel_2011" /> In the early 21st century, illegal immigrants were reportedly subject to patient dumping by being deported or repatriated.<ref name="Abel_2011" /> Research articles also describe dumping of homeless individuals or mentally ill individuals by police as another form of inappropriately shifting people from one area of a city to another instead of taking them to adequate care facilities like shelters.<ref>{{Cite journal|last1=King|first1=William R.|last2=Dunn|first2=Thomas M.|title=Dumping: Police-Initiated Transjurisdictional Transport of Troublesome Persons|journal=Police Quarterly|volume=7|issue=3|pages=339–358|doi=10.1177/1098611102250586|year=2004|s2cid=145503255|url=http://pqx.sagepub.com/content/7/3/339.full.pdf}}</ref> In September 2014, the U.S. Commission on Civil Rights issued a report entitled "Patient Dumping".<ref>U.S. Commission on Civil Rights, [https://www.usccr.gov/pubs/docs/2014PATDUMPOSD_9282014-1.pdf Patient Dumping] (September 2014).</ref>
== Statistics == A report published in 2001 by [[Public Citizen]]'s Health Research Group stated that there were widespread violations of EMTALA throughout the United States in 527 hospitals.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.citizen.org/our-work/health-and-safety/questionable-hospitals-2001-patient-dumping-hospital-emergency|title=Questionable Hospitals 2001: Patient Dumping by Hospital Emergency Rooms|website=Public Citizen}}</ref> Between 2005 and 2014 another study reported 43% of the US hospitals studied had been under EMTALA investigation which resulted citations for 27% of the hospitals.<ref name=":2">{{Cite journal|last1=Terp|first1=Sophie|last2=Seabury|first2=Seth A.|last3=Arora|first3=Sanjay|last4=Eads|first4=Andrew|last5=Lam|first5=Chun Nok|last6=Menchine|first6=Michael|date=February 2017|title=Enforcement of the Emergency Medical Treatment and Labor Act, 2005 to 2014|journal=Annals of Emergency Medicine|volume=69|issue=2|pages=155–162.e1|doi=10.1016/j.annemergmed.2016.05.021|issn=1097-6760|pmid=27496388|pmc=7176068}}</ref> The other findings of this study were that the number of EMTALA violations have been decreasing for the period between 2005 and 2014, and that the majority of the citations were given to hospitals for issues with policy enforcement.<ref name=":2" /> However, there is not a consensus among researchers about how to effectively measure the effects of EMTALA at reducing patient dumping or improving patient care.<ref name=":2" />
== Associated factors == Patients living in poverty or in homelessness are often seen as less than ideal patients for hospital administrations because they are unlikely to be able to pay for their healthcare and tend to be hospitalized with severe illness.<ref name="Abel_2011" /><ref name="Rice_1992" /> Other factors associated with patient dumping are being part of a minority group and being uninsured.<ref name="Rice_1992" /> Historically, hospitals have been reported to compete against each other to maintain low mortality rates at the expense of low-income patients.<ref name="Abel_2011" /><ref name="Rice_1992" /> Competition within hospitals to see more patients and faster also increases the rate of inappropriate patient discharges.<ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Kellermann AL, Hackman BB | title = Patient 'dumping' post-COBRA | journal = American Journal of Public Health | volume = 80 | issue = 7 | pages = 864–7 | date = July 1990 | pmid = 2356913 | pmc = 1404974 | doi = 10.2105/AJPH.80.7.864 }}</ref>
Some researchers and scholars trace the issue of homeless dumping to the issue of homelessness and claim that addressing the issues of homelessness will prevent patient dumping.<ref name="Cohen_1992" /> The increase of homelessness and poverty rates increases the number of people who are unable to pay for consistent healthcare which leads to emergency hospitalization of patients with exacerbated medical conditions.<ref name="Fader_2012">{{cite journal | vauthors = Fader HC, Phillips CN | title = Frequent-user patients: reducing costs while making appropriate discharges | journal = Healthcare Financial Management | volume = 66 | issue = 3 | pages = 98–100, 102, 104 passim | date = March 2012 | pmid = 22420142 }}</ref> Social factors have allowed homelessness and poverty rates to further increase, and deinstitutionalization has led to psychiatric patients to lose access to services and be dumped on the streets.<ref name="Cohen_1992">{{cite journal | vauthors = Cohen CI, Thompson KC | title = Psychiatry and the homeless | journal = Biological Psychiatry | volume = 32 | issue = 5 | pages = 383–6 | date = September 1992 | pmid = 1486144 | doi = 10.1016/0006-3223(92)90126-k | s2cid = 13562583 }}</ref>
== Intervention strategies == The introduction of Medicaid and Medicare had helped hospitals shoulder the burden of providing care to poverty-level and elderly patients, but the many people in United States without health insurance were still vulnerable to inappropriate patient transfer or dumping.<ref name="Rice_1992" /> Scholars and researchers point to these patients' lack of access to preventative and consistent healthcare treatment as well as inappropriate discharge procedures and follow-up protocols as the causes behind the frequent rehospitalization.<ref name="Fader_2012" />
In 1985 Illinois developed the Illinois Competitive Access and Reimbursement Equity (ICARE) program, but it had adverse effects like disrupting indigent patient's continuity of care, losing patients, and creating two hospital systems: one for uninsured lower-income patients and one for insured higher-income patients.<ref name="Rice_1992" /><ref name="Brider_1987" /> The ICARE policy had a negative impact on the quality of healthcare that low-income and homeless patients received because it created disjointed treatment experiences when hospitals met their allocated funding quota and transferred patients to (or dumped patients on) other hospitals that still had funding and public hospitals.<ref name="Brider_1987" /> Proponents of the ICARE policy cited the reduction in Illinois' Medicare expenditure as evidence of the policy's success.<ref name="Brider_1987" />
The 1986 Emergency Medical Treatment and Active Labor Act (EMTALA) was meant to regulate Medicare-participating hospitals and ensure that patients received appropriate medical treatment regardless of their ability to pay.<ref name="Kahntroff_2009">{{cite journal | vauthors = Kahntroff J, Watson R | title = Refusal of emergency care and patient dumping | journal = The Virtual Mentor | volume = 11 | issue = 1 | pages = 49–53 | date = January 2009 | pmid = 23190486 | doi = 10.1001/virtualmentor.2009.11.1.hlaw1-0901 }}</ref> Some scholars described how EMTALA provided a means to take legal action against healthcare providers and hospitals that did not comply, and provided examples of cases in Florida, California, and North Carolina.<ref name="Kahntroff_2009" /> Even though hospitals have had to pay penalties, patient dumping remained an issue throughout the country.<ref name="Kahntroff_2009" /> Legal scholars Kahntroff and Watson (2009) also reported that the implementation of the policy has been flawed with issues of lack of adherence and confusion on what is compliance.<ref name="Kahntroff_2009" /> A study that looked at 5,594 hospitals in the United States between 2005 and 2014 reported that the number of EMTALA investigations has decreased through that period which may be an indication that hospitals and physicians are improving their adherence to EMTALA protocols.<ref name=":2" /> The decrease in EMTALA investigations might also indicate that patient access to emergency care and treatment is improving.<ref name=":2" /> Researchers also interviewed doctors who reported that EMTALA citation fines were a disincentive to violate EMTALA protocols.<ref name=":2" />
In 1988 the COBRA Act was meant to be a series of revised regulations which required hospital emergency rooms to treat every patient that walked through the door and doubled the fine for violations.<ref name="Rice_1992" /> News Editor for the ''American Journal of Nursing'', Brider (1987), reported that public hospital staff in Illinois were under a lot of pressure due to the influx of patients that were being sent to them from other hospitals, and that the incidence of patient transfers or patient dumping increased through a loophole in COBRA.<ref name="Brider_1987" />
The incentives offered to doctors in terms of payment for their services have an effect with patient care outcomes and can minimize the chance of patient dumping or shifting patients to other providers.<ref name=":1">{{Cite journal|last1=Greene|first1=Jessica|last2=Kurtzman|first2=Ellen T.|last3=Hibbard|first3=Judith H.|last4=Overton|first4=Valerie|date=2015-05-01|title=Working Under a Clinic-Level Quality Incentive: Primary Care Clinicians' Perceptions|journal=The Annals of Family Medicine|language=en|volume=13|issue=3|pages=235–241|doi=10.1370/afm.1779|issn=1544-1709|pmid=25964401|pmc=4427418}}</ref> A study conducted on doctors at the Fairview Health Services hospital in Minnesota reported that grouping doctors into teams to incentivize collaboration between the doctors to ensure the average of the team provided high quality health care for the patient.<ref name=":1" /> But doctors who out performed other doctors on their teams did not like the program because the other doctors who were underperforming did not have the incentive to improve. Some of the doctors interviewed in the study claimed that underperforming doctors would only start providing better care if their pay was affected by their lower quality services.
=== Discussion of intervention strategies === Some researchers and scholars have concluded that despite the policy interventions of the 1980s, the practice of patient dumping continued to be a problem in the United States and that a solution required a reformation of the entire healthcare system.<ref name="Abel_2011" /><ref name="Rice_1992" /> These researchers shared the opinion that the most effective solution to address the health care needs of people living in poverty and those who are homeless is to provide universal healthcare because that would eliminate hospitals incentives to turn patients away based on their ability to pay for services.<ref name="Abel_2011" /><ref name="Rice_1992" /><ref name="Kahntroff_2009" /> Other researchers emphasize that better developed protocols and procedures for patient discharge are one of the most important strategies to reduce rehospitalization rates because patients living in homelessness and poverty lack appropriate dwelling to continue the recuperation process.<ref name="Hochron_2013">{{cite journal | last1 = Hochron | first1 = Jean L. | last2 = Brown | first2 = Ellen M. | name-list-style = vanc | date = June 2013 | title = Ensuring Appropriate Discharge Practices for Hospitalized Homeless Patients | journal = World Medical & Health Policy | volume = 5 | issue = 2 | pages = 175–181 | doi = 10.1002/wmh3.37 }}</ref><ref name="Fader_2012" /> Another strategy to minimize rehospitalization rates proposed by researchers was to create recuperation programs for patient who lack access to one after they are discharge.<ref name="Fader_2012" /> Respite programs can be especially helpful for homeless patients to have safe places to recuperate and stop the cycle of chronic re-admittance.<ref name=":0">{{Cite journal|last1=Doran|first1=Kelly M.|last2=Greysen|first2=S. Ryan|last3=Cunningham|first3=Alison|last4=Tynan-McKiernan|first4=Kathleen|last5=Lucas|first5=Georgina I.|last6=Rosenthal|first6=Marjorie S.|title=Improving post-hospital care for people who are homeless: Community-based participatory research to community-based action|journal=Healthcare|volume=3|issue=4|pages=238–244|doi=10.1016/j.hjdsi.2015.07.006|pmid=26699351|year=2015}}</ref> A study conducted using information about homeless patients in New Haven, Connecticut, reported that homeless patients had a 22% higher hospital readmittance rate than patients with insurance.<ref name=":0" />
Regional or community wide programs to oversee under-resourced patient recuperation or respite care seem to be the most sustainable because they pool resources from multiple hospitals and a larger population to provide appropriate recuperation facilities and minimize the risk of any one hospital or healthcare facility from having to provide the majority of the resources and cost associated with the increase of patients from the area's underserved patient population.<ref name="Fader_2012" /> Researchers say that the cost of rehospitalizing patients for more critical conditions is higher than the cost of providing appropriate healthcare and following careful patient discharge procedures, which in some cases are beyond the requirements outlined by policies like the EMTALA.<ref name="Fader_2012" />
However, there are studies that have indicated that hospitals sometimes face delays when discharging a homeless patient because they also have the responsibility of finding appropriate housing and care.<ref name=":0" /> Extended hospitalization increases the chance of infectious disease transmission and draws resources from other patients.<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":4">{{Cite journal|last1=Hendy|first1=P.|last2=Patel|first2=J. H.|last3=Kordbacheh|first3=T.|last4=Laskar|first4=N.|last5=Harbord|first5=M.|date=August 2012|title=In-depth analysis of delays to patient discharge: a metropolitan teaching hospital experience|journal=Clinical Medicine|volume=12|issue=4|pages=320–323|issn=1470-2118|pmid=22930874|pmc=4952118|doi=10.7861/clinmedicine.12-4-320}}</ref>
== Global perspective ==
=== Canada === A study conducted on physicians in Ontario investigated how different payment systems impacted patient care in terms of the number of cost shifts and dumping incidences{{verify spelling|date=September 2022|reason=''incidence'' is normally used only in the singular form, perhaps ''incidents'' was intended}} and reported that other factors like altruism or ethics of the doctors and patient behavior played a role in how doctors shifted costs.<ref>{{Cite journal|last1=Kantarevic|first1=Jasmin|last2=Kralj|first2=Boris|title=Risk selection and cost shifting in a prospective physician payment system: Evidence from Ontario|journal=Health Policy|volume=115|issue=2–3|pages=249–257|doi=10.1016/j.healthpol.2013.10.002|pmid=24210763|year=2014}}</ref> Some researchers hold the view that the [[Healthcare in Canada|Canadian healthcare system]] is better designed to minimize the occurrences of patient dumping.<ref name="Rice_1992" />
=== Taiwan === A study published in 2006 that used voluntary surveys in its methods claimed that the results of the surveys indicated patient dumping was a problem within [[Taiwan]]'s healthcare system.<ref name="Lin_2006">{{cite journal | vauthors = Lin HC, Kao S, Tang CH, Yang MC, Lee HS | title = Factors contributing to patient dumping in Taiwan | journal = Health Policy | volume = 77 | issue = 1 | pages = 103–12 | date = June 2006 | pmid = 16150511 | doi = 10.1016/j.healthpol.2005.07.009 | url = http://ntur.lib.ntu.edu.tw//bitstream/246246/158857/1/37.pdf }}</ref> Researchers report that funding issues with government budgets and pressure that hospitals felt to stay competitive were among of the contributing factors to patient dumping.<ref name="Lin_2006" /> A previous study published in 2003 also supported the claim that Taiwan's healthcare system is negatively impacted by patient dumping in terms of healthcare quality and increased costs.<ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Lin HC, Yang MC, Chen CC, Tang CH | title = Opinions of hospital administrators toward the prevalence of patient dumping in Taiwan | journal = Chang Gung Medical Journal | volume = 27 | issue = 1 | pages = 35–43 | date = January 2004 | pmid = 15074888 }}</ref>
=== United Kingdom === In the a study conducted in the [[United Kingdom]] the issue of inappropriately discharging a patient has more to do with delaying the discharge than expediting the discharge.<ref name=":4" /> In 2004 a report was published in the UK that claimed that prisons were overcrowded and that one of the populations at risk of living in adverse conditions were mentally ill incarcerated individuals who were dumped in prisons.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Davies|first=Rachael|title=Deaths in UK prisons are due to overcrowding, says report|journal=The Lancet|volume=363|issue=9406|pages=378|doi=10.1016/s0140-6736(04)15481-0|pmid=15074304|year=2004|s2cid=2175221}}</ref>
==Usage==
=== Other associated names or terms === Other terms used in related to the practice of patient dumping are frequent-user patient, revolving-door, and bed block-blockers.<ref name="Fader_2012" /> These terms were contrived by some hospital staff who noted how these patients had reoccurring hospitalizations.<ref name="Fader_2012" /> Other ways homeless dumping is described is with phrases like inappropriate patient discharges and economically motivated transfers.<ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Schlesinger M, Dorwart R, Hoover C, Epstein S | title = The determinants of dumping: a national study of economically motivated transfers involving mental health care | journal = Health Services Research | volume = 32 | issue = 5 | pages = 561–90 | date = December 1997 | pmid = 9402901 | pmc = 1070215 }}</ref>
=== Usage in the media and press === *[[Associated Press]]; February 9, 2007; [[Los Angeles]]. A hospital van dropped off a homeless paraplegic man on [[Skid Row, Los Angeles|Skid Row]] and left him crawling in the street with nothing more than a soiled gown and a broken colostomy bag, police said.... Police said the incident was a case of ''"homeless dumping"'' and were questioning officials from the hospital.<ref>[http://www.nbcnews.com/id/17062674 Police probe alleged L.A. homeless dumping: Hospital van reportedly spotted dropping off paraplegic man on Skid Row], [[NBC News]] via [[Associated Press]], February 9, 2007</ref> *[[Associated Press]], October 25, 2006; [[Los Angeles]]. "L.A. Police Allege ''Homeless Dumping''." Authorities have launched a criminal investigation into suspected dumping of homeless people on Skid Row after police witnessed ambulances leaving five people on a street there during the weekend.
